And third, at the Snapdragon Summit, we unveiled the Snapdragon 8 Elite handset platform, featuring the world's fastest mobile CPU; and the Snapdragon Cockpit Elite and Snapdragon Ride Elite automotive platforms, establishing us as a performance leader in digital cockpit and ADAS. Lastly, we look forward to seeing you in New York on November 19, where we will expand on these exciting product announcements with an update on our IoT and automotive diversification strategy. This concludes our prepared remarks. Back to you, Mauricio.

transcript.speaker: Mauricio Lopez-Hodoyan
transcript.title: VP of Investor Relations
transcript.content: Thank you, Akash. Operator, we are now ready for questions.

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: The first question comes from Joe Moore with Morgan Stanley.

transcript.speaker: Joseph Moore
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Great. Wondering if you could talk about the strength in autos, you've obviously put up great sequential numbers, there are headwinds in that business. I know you have a lot of pipeline momentum, but just kind of give us a picture of how the environment is affecting you and how much visibility you have into that trajectory?

transcript.speaker: Cristiano Amon
transcript.title: CEO
transcript.content: Joe, thanks for the question. This is Cristiano. As we said before, I think you should look at our revenue in auto as less sensitive to what happens in the market, much more related to new models that are being launched with Qualcomm technology, and it's reflecting a shift in share. So as we gain share and new models get launched, you started to see that show up in our financials. So that's the reason we continue to have growth both sequentially and year-over-year.

transcript.speaker: Joseph Moore
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Great. And then I don't think you mentioned it. Anything you could say about the ARM dispute? Because that would help us understand what's the stake there.

transcript.speaker: Akash Palkhiwala
transcript.title: CFO
transcript.content: Yes. Joe, on the ARM side, from our perspective, we have very broad, well-established license rights that cover our custom design CPUs. So we are very confident that those rights will be affirmed. The trial is scheduled for December, and so we're looking forward to addressing ARM's claims at that point.

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: The next question is from the line of Samik Chatterjee with JPMorgan.

transcript.speaker: Samik Chatterjee
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Really strong results, so congratulations on that. Maybe if I can start with IoT. For the first 3 quarters of the year, you had declines on a year-over-year basis. And we're seeing this sort of acceleration in IoT in the fourth quarter and going into the first quarter on a year-over-year basis. Can you just sort of parse that out a bit? How much of this is a recovery in sort of the traditional IoT businesses you are in relative to contributions from the PC market and really an acceleration on account of that? Just anything you can parse out between industrial IoT, consumer IoT, new products versus older products you've been on. And I have a follow-up.

transcript.speaker: Akash Palkhiwala
transcript.title: CFO
transcript.content: Sure. So Samik, it's Akash. If you look at our performance both in the fourth quarter and first quarter in IoT, we saw benefits across all 3 areas: consumer, industrial, and networking. And within the fourth quarter, as some new products were launched in PC, XR, and other areas as well, we saw the benefits of those launches come through in our numbers. There is a portion of channel inventory normalization as well, but it's really the new product launches kind of coming through for us both in the fourth and first quarter. And that sets us up well for the rest of the year.

transcript.speaker: Samik Chatterjee
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: I understand. It’s been a challenging macroeconomic environment, and you're projecting about a 10% revenue growth in the first quarter. I'm considering the sustainability of that into the March quarter, especially since you mentioned some acceleration in Android launches. How can we assess the combination of smartphone performance along with your strong results in non-smartphone areas? How sustainable do you think this double-digit growth will be going into the March quarter?

transcript.speaker: Akash Palkhiwala
transcript.title: CFO
transcript.content: Yes. Samik, so we're pretty happy with the trajectory of the business both in terms of our fourth quarter results and first quarter guidance. We are not guiding beyond the first quarter at this point. But as you know, we have an Investor Day coming up in a couple of weeks, where we're going to talk through our diversification strategy and growth, and we'll provide a financial framework around it. So we'll address some of these topics at that point.

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: The next question is from the line of Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein Research.

transcript.speaker: Stacy Rasgon
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: My first question, just on chipset gross margins, they seem to be guided down a bit, I don't know, 100 or 150 basis points in Q1. Is that just increased wafer cost, or is there something else going on with mix just given which products are shipping? Any color you can give us on gross margins? And I guess, like is the framework on how to think about them going forward around 48-ish, plus or minus? Is that still the right way to think about chip gross margins?

transcript.speaker: Akash Palkhiwala
transcript.title: CFO
transcript.content: Yes. Sure, Stacy, it's Akash. So in the fourth quarter, we actually guided lower, and we came in slightly better because of stronger mix. And so what we're guiding in the first quarter is really largely in line with the fourth quarter, and we think that's kind of a reasonable way to model the business going forward. And I think from a product mix perspective, we feel pretty good about where we are set up both across businesses and within handsets.

transcript.speaker: Stacy Rasgon
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Got it. For my follow-up, I just wanted to ask a little more about PCs. You talked about new product launches in Q4. Can you help us size, like how big was the PC portion in Q4? And given you're guiding IoT down seasonally, sequentially in Q1, is PCs as well as some of the other stuff a function of that? Like how do we think about the contribution that we're seeing early in the launch of those products?

transcript.speaker: Akash Palkhiwala
transcript.title: CFO
transcript.content: Yes. So Stacy, as you know, we're pretty excited about the PC roadmap. I think we've kind of established ourselves as a performance leader in Windows devices. And during the quarter, we also launched a new chip, Snapdragon X Plus 8-core chip, which allows us now to access the $700 price tier for the PC market as well. So now we have performance leadership really without compromising on NPU performance across tiers in the PC market. And so initial reaction has been great. We are pleased with it. We will talk about this in a lot more detail at Investor Day, both from traction across OEMs and then targets for the longer term.

transcript.speaker: Cristiano Amon
transcript.title: CEO
transcript.content: Stacy, this is Cristiano. I wanted to add something. While we plan to discuss financial projections for the PC business on November 19, I want to highlight a notable point. Since our launch in May, which was just a short time ago, we've seen significant progress. At launch, we had around 20 platforms, and now we have about 58 platforms designed and in development. This nearly threefold increase in platforms is boosting our confidence that our offering resonates with the market, and we're gaining traction with OEMs.

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: Our next question is from Joshua Buchalter with TD Cowen.

transcript.speaker: Joshua Buchalter
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: I wanted to follow up on Joe's question from earlier about the auto upside. I mean, in particular, the auto space upside has been driven by China. I guess, maybe you could give us some data points on how much your exposure within the auto market is driven by the China market now? And then also maybe some metrics you can give us on how much is infotainment versus ADAS? And in particular, as you ramp Snapdragon Ride Elite with capabilities of both infotainment and ADAS on one SoC, how is engagement for that? And how do you expect that to ramp over the next couple of years?

transcript.speaker: Akash Palkhiwala
transcript.title: CFO
transcript.content: Josh, it's Akash. From a geography diversity perspective, you should think of our portfolio as very diverse. We have a very strong set of design wins globally across OEMs. And so you should not think of this as reliant on a specific geography. And we are planning to give some disclosures on that topic as we go forward.

transcript.speaker: Cristiano Amon
transcript.title: CEO
transcript.content: Maybe just to kind of add one thing. I think in addition to design with virtually every single OEM and every region, one of the things we're very excited about is what we did on both the Snapdragon Ride Elite and Cockpit Elite. One of the things I want to point out is it's one of the biggest upgrades to date in order of magnitude, about 12x on AI. As we said before, I think GenAI use cases on a car, especially a little different approach, is about future-proofing that design for software-defined vehicles, is getting a lot of traction to a lot of OEMs. We announced two that made public, but I think design traction on that chipset is actually very high.

transcript.speaker: Akash Palkhiwala
transcript.title: CFO
transcript.content: And Josh, on your second question regarding a combination of cockpit and ADAS, a lot of our traction this year is with launches of cars using our cockpit solution. And we see ADAS having some traction and some deployments right now, but it's going to ramp over the next couple of years. And that becomes another inflection point in our revenue growth going forward.

transcript.speaker: Joshua Buchalter
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Got it. Thank you for all the color. And then a follow-up, I wanted to ask about the handset market. If we sort of back out your top 2 customers, handsets are up, I think, around 50% year-over-year. Any metrics you can give us on units versus ASPs? I know there was an inventory dynamic last year. So as we think about the sustainability of that growth vector into 2025, in particular, for the China market, would be curious if there's any incremental metrics you can give us outside your top 2 customers.

transcript.speaker: Akash Palkhiwala
transcript.title: CFO
transcript.content: Yes, Josh, in the overall handset market, we are projecting a growth of low to mid-single digits for 2024 based on sell-through data. The key highlight for us has been the increase in content. We’ve observed that chipsets are becoming significantly more advanced, as evidenced by the announcement of X Elite 8 Elite last month, which incorporates much more content into the chip. As these solutions gain traction, we also experience positive impacts on the average selling price. Additionally, the distribution across different tiers is improving in the handset market. So if you kind of look back over the last 3 or 4 years, devices greater than $400 have gone up from being 21% of the market to 30% of the market, and that is definitely beneficial to us. Maybe one last point is, if you think about our guidance for the December quarter, we do not have any Huawei product revenue in our guidance. A year ago quarter, we did have Huawei product revenue. So it's actually something that we have overcome, and then we have growth on top of it.

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: Our next question is from Chris Caso with Wolfe Research.

transcript.speaker: Christopher Caso
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Just another follow-up question regarding handsets. And if you could kind of characterize because I think for Qualcomm, you saw a rebound or normalization in the premium part of the handset market in the first half of the year. Is what you're seeing now some follow-through on the mid-tier or is it just kind of continuation of what you saw in the first half of the year? And then secondly on that, with regard to some of the accelerated China launches, do you think that's a reflection of the market, or some perhaps improvement in the market in China or at least the China OEMs? Or is it simply a matter of timing?

transcript.speaker: Akash Palkhiwala
transcript.title: CFO
transcript.content: Yes. I think, Chris, if you think about our handset business, we're definitely really strong at the top of the roadmap in the premium tier. And as we mentioned earlier, we announced our new flagship chipset, and you're seeing OEMs launch with that chipset. So those definitely factor into our numbers. And it's less about other tiers, more about the fact that we launched our new premium-tier chipset, and the OEMs are actively taking advantage of it by accelerating their launches and really increasing the scale of their launches. Yes. It's very much normal. It's really the extra week coming out and the normal sequential quarter-over-quarter growth.

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: The next question is from Tal Liani with Bank of America.

transcript.speaker: Tal Liani
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Other companies reported kind of opposite trends of what you're talking about. Some of the companies reported weakness in China migration to lower tier, and then Apple had kind of weaker numbers than expected. How do you connect the comments we get from other vendors to your strengths? And are you concerned that maybe the strength is more inventory build-out or build-out by customers because of your new launches? So can you comment about end-market demand and the composition of end-market demands globally?

transcript.speaker: Cristiano Amon
transcript.title: CEO
transcript.content: Look, thanks for the question. I can't really speak of other companies. The only thing I can say is I'm actually very happy with our results. But I'll give you a couple of data points to help you triangulate that. When we look sequentially, we have now quarter-over-quarter greater than 40% handset revenue growth with Chinese OEMs as we look into the 1Q fiscal '25, if you look at the guide. In fiscal '24, our Android revenues showed 20% year-over-year growth, including the loss of Huawei revenues. And when we compare with our closest competitor, for example, in Android, our premium tier, we reported greater than 5x the premium-tier revenue. So I think it shows a couple of things. As Akash outlined, content is increasing. The premium tier is expanding in the market and stabilizing. And we don't see much of the inventory dynamics we used to see. So I think it speaks a little bit to the strength of our product roadmap and the launch of new products from customers in China, but more importantly, this trend that the mix is really improving.

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: The next question is from Timothy Arcuri with UBS.

transcript.speaker: Timothy Arcuri
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Akash, I'm looking at the guidance, and for China Android to increase by more than 40%, it suggests that your two other major customers are both experiencing declines in the double digits. They both must be down. Can you elaborate on that? It's unusual for at least one of these customers to be in a downturn. Additionally, can you explain what is driving this situation? Do you think there's any possibility that this is due to customers trying to adjust their orders ahead of potential tariffs, especially in light of the recent election results? Would that be a reasonable assumption?

transcript.speaker: Akash Palkhiwala
transcript.title: CFO
transcript.content: Let me address the second part of your question. That's not accurate. This isn't related to tariffs or pull-forward effects for those reasons. From the customer perspective regarding quarterly trends, our guidance is influenced by customer launch schedules and their needs. This shouldn't be viewed as a commentary on sell-through; it actually concerns chipset purchases being made from us. These two aspects may be unrelated in some instances. However, you are already aware of our market share among OEMs. So this isn't a question of market share; it's really about the timing of purchases from us.

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: Our final question will be from C.J. Muse with Cantor Fitzgerald.

transcript.speaker: Christopher Muse
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: I guess the first question was hoping to revisit the IoT business growing nicely for you year-on-year, and pretty much every other company that I've come across is seeing challenges there, particularly parts of consumer and industrial. So would love to hear perhaps on the consumer side, whether you're seeing kind of the uptake that we're hearing in China. And then moreover, I guess, on the industrial side, is that where you're seeing inventory correction? What's the timing of recovery and your thoughts there?

transcript.speaker: Akash Palkhiwala
transcript.title: CFO
transcript.content: Yes. Sure. So on the consumer side, as we said, new product launches, both in XR and in PC, are definitely a factor in our performance. And then on the industrial side, at the Embedded World, we announced a new product portfolio, updated product portfolio that addresses both not just chipsets but software readiness to drive through AI-ready use cases in industrial. We think that the market is turning. There's an inflection point, and there's going to be a lot of demand for solutions that have processing, connectivity, and AI readiness. And so we're seeing these early stages of demand come through for our solutions. And this is one of the topics that we'll discuss in detail at our Investor Day. So stay tuned on that one.

transcript.speaker: Christopher Muse
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Very helpful. And as a follow-up, in your 10-K, you talked about a large customer potentially going internal as a next several quarter risk. And obviously, this has been discussed for many years. But if it were to happen, how should we think about the moving parts to your overall QCT margins?

transcript.speaker: Akash Palkhiwala
transcript.title: CFO
transcript.content: I think no real change, no new information here. I think there's enough data out there for you to be able to size the risk that we've always outlined. As we've said, we have a 3-year agreement, '24, '25, and '26 phone launches, and the framework of that agreement is consistent with the prior one. Our planning assumption has been that the share will ramp down to 20% for the '26 launch, and the agreement ends after that. So no change really to anything we've said in the past, and I think that's how our planning assumption is. Anything better would be upside.

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: That concludes our question-and-answer session. Mr. Amon, do you have anything further to add before adjourning the call?

transcript.speaker: Cristiano Amon
transcript.title: CEO
transcript.content: Thank you all for joining us today. We feel confident about our position at Qualcomm. There are very few companies that can operate across so many markets and industries undergoing transformation. Despite the distractions in the environment, we remain focused on our growth and diversification strategy. We're excited to share more of our story on November 19. I also want to express my gratitude to all our employees for a fantastic fiscal year 2024. They are truly the heart of Qualcomm. We are committed to executing our plans and evolving the company into a leading connected computing firm for the AI era. Thank you, and I look forward to our next conversation next quarter.

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.
